questions.text: Halbans disease is otherwise called as
questions.solution:
• Endometrial pattern in irregular shedding : Endometrial sapling performed after 5th or 6th day of the onset of menstruation reveals a mixture of secretory and proliferative endometrium. There is total absence of any surface epithelium
  • Endometrial pattern in irregular ripening: Endometrial study prior to or soon after spotting reveals patchy area of secretory changes amidst proliferative endometrium

questions.text: Degree of inversion if fundus of the uterus protrudes through the cervix and lies in the vagina is
questions.solution:
Degrees of Uterine Inversion

  1. Dimpling
  2. Fundus comes to the level of cervix
  3. Fundus lies in the vagina
  4. Fundus is outside the vagina

questions.text: Most common cause of secondary PPH is
questions.solution:
• Secondary postpartum hemorrhage is bleeding between 24 hrs to 12 weeks after delivery
  • It is caused by retention of a placental fragment or by a uterine artery pseudoaneurysm. Usually, retained products undergo necrosis with fibrin deposition and may eventually form a so called placental polyp. As the eschar of the polyp detaches from the myometrium, hemorrhage may be risk.

questions.text: Highest chances of ureteric injury is seen with
questions.solution:
Types of hysterectomy




  • Type IV Hysterectomy → Superior vesical artery also removed Not done now a days
  • Type V Hysterectomy → Exenteration Sx

questions.text: What is the associated complication
questions.solution:
• Vasa Previa is a particularly dangerous variation of velamentous insertion in which the vessels within the membrances overlie the cervical os
  • Incidence is 1 in 5200 pregnancies
  • Risk factors include bilobate or succenturiate placentas and second trimester placenta previa, with or without later migration
  • It is also increased in pregnancies conceived by in vitro fertilization
  • Once vasa previa is identified, early scheduled caesarean delivery is planned
  • In many cases, bleeding is rapidly fatal, and infant salvage is not possible. With less hemorrhage, however, it may be possible to distinguish fetal versus maternal bleeding

questions.text: Tobaccco juice like liquor is seen in
25 year old primigravid woman presents with idiopathic polyhydramnios for which she is started on indomethacin. Fetus should be monitored for
questions.solution: Prostaglandins keep the ductus patent and NSAIDS cause premature closure of ductus arteriosus

questions.text: The following pressure increases during pregnancy
questions.solution:
Femorl venous pressure for a non pregnant woman is 8 mm Hg and during pregnancy it becomes 24 mm hg

  • Both systolic and diastolic blood pressure fall during pregnancy but diastolic pressure falls more than systolic pressure.
  • Fall in blood pressure begins by 6 weeks.
  • Fall is maximum by 24-26 weeks (2nd trimester)

questions.text: The following remains unaltered change during pregnancy
questions.solution:
Cardiovascular changes in pregnancy

  1. Heart rate increased by 10-15 beats/mt
  2. Apex beat shifts to 4th intercostal space, 2.5 cm outside the midclavicular line.
  3. Enlarged cardiac silhoutte
  4. Exagerated splitting of S1/second heart sound normal.
  5. Third heart sound loud and easily auscultated.
  6. Echo- increased left atrial and ventricular diameters
  7. ECG- Left axis deviation
  8. Murmurs

Gr 2- ESM- aortic and pulmonary area

Continuous hissing murmur audible over the tricuspid area- left 2/3rd ICS. Mammary murmur.

questions.text: The only adrenal hormone that decreases during pregnancy is
questions.solution: All the adrenal hormones increase during pregnancy except DHEAS.

questions.text: All of the following are used to estimate the fetal weight except
questions.solution:
Estimation of fetal weight

Johnson’s formula:

  • Height of uterus above pubic symphysis (cm)-12 x 155 gives fetal weight in gram (if head is above ischial sp
  • Height of uterus above pubic symphysis(cm)-11 x 155 gives fetal weight in gram (if head is below ischial spine)

Other formulas based on USG measurements

  1. Sheperd formula
  2. Hadlocks formula

questions.text: The following is a clinical method of estimating the fetal weight
questions.solution:
• Johnson’s Formula:
    • Height Of Uterus Above Pubic Symphysis (Cm)-12* 155 (gives estimated fetal weight in gram) (If Head Is Above Ischial Spine)
    • Height Of Uterus Above Pubic Symphysis(Cm)-11* 155 (gives estimated fetal weight in gram) (If Head Is Below Ischial Spine)

Other Formulas Based On Usg Measurements

  1. Sheperd Formula
  2. Hadlocks Formula

questions.solution:

  5. Incidence of sensitization with Anti-D immunoprophylaxis is - < 0.2%

Types of deceleration

questions.text: Alpha feto protein is not elevated in
questions.solution:
AFP passes from urine of fetus into amniotic fluid and enters maternal serum by diffusion.

Therefore any defect in fetus wall will result in more of mixing in amniotic fluid and hence increased MSAFP

MSAFP

questions.text: Screening method of Downs with least sensitivity is

A 25 Years Old Female Reports To Casualty With History Of Amenorrhea For 2 And Half Months, C/O Of Bleeding P.V For 1 Day. On Examination Vital Parameters Are Normal. Bleeding Is Seen From Os On Speculum E. On Bimanual Examination- Uterus Is 10 Weeks And Os Admits One Finger. The Diagnosis Is
Studiford criteria is used to diagnose
questions.solution:

    • Pregnancy Related Exclusively To Peritoneal Surface

questions.text: At full term pregnancy all of the following parameters are raised except

choices.text: Review after 2-3 months for ovarian cyst

questions.text: A 26 year old female presents in OPD for dull aching lower abdomen pain. She had previous two normal vaginal deliveries. Her LMP was 3 weeks ago. On P/V examination a cystic mass was felt in the left fornix region, which on USG was found to be a left clear ovarian cyst of 5 cm. which of the following is recommended for this patient
questions.solution:
Corpus luteum (granulose lutein) cysts are functional, non-neoplastic enlargements of the ovary. Persistent cor-pus luteum cyst may cause local pain, tenderness or delayed menstruation. These cysts are often palpable clinically. Unless complication like torsion or rupture lead to an acute abdomen requiring surgical treatment, most cysts will resolve in due course of time. Hence observation is recommended whenever this condition is suspected.

Functional cysts are recognized from neoplastic cyst by the fact that they never grow more than 7cm in size, are unilocular with clear fluid and regress after some time.

questions.text: A 25 year old female visits OPD for intertility treatment. During evaluation, hysteroscopy was done and was diagnosed to have Ashermann syndrome. Which of the following symptom the patient is excepted to have
questions.solution:
Most patients present with hypomenorrhea before amenorrhea sets in. Ashermann’s syndrome is amenorrhea due to intrauterine synechiae formation. M/C cause of ashermann’s syndrome is vigorous uterine curettage in postpartum period but the syndrome can also occur after myomectomy, caesarean section and tuberculosis endometritis.

Management: Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis followed by insertion of CuT to prevent reformation of synechiae and cyclical estrogen and progesterone.

questions.text: A 39 year old female para 2, complains of severe progressive secondary dysmennorhea. Pelvic examination revealed a tender diffuse enlarged uterus with no adnexal tenderness. Endometrium biopsy came normal. The diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Adenomyosis:

Adenomyosis is a condition where there is ingrowth of endometrium (both gland + stroma) directly into the myometrium. Earlier it was called as endometriosis interna.

Age Group: Elderly patients > 40 years

Parity: Multiparous

Symptoms:

  • Most common symptom: Menorrhagia
  • 2nd most common symptom: Dysmenorrhea
  • Others: Pelvic discomfort, backache, dyspareunia

On per vaginal examination: Symmetrical enlargement of uterus (not more than 12-14 weeks of pregnancy), mobility not restricted, no associated adnexal pathology.

Halbans sign- Tender, softened uterus on premenstrual bimanual examination.

Diagnosis:

  • Mainly Clinical
  • Transvaginal ultrasonography or MRI (Junctional zone thickness > 12 mm) are helpful

Management:

  • Surgery
  • Levonorgestrel containing IUCDs

questions.text: A primigravida had a normal spontaneous vaginal delivery without complications. The placenta was removed fully and was intact. She starts to bleed profusely after 1/2 an hour. Physical examination reveals a boggy uterus and USG showed placental tissue. The most probable diagnosis is
questions.solution:
A placenta containing three or more equally sized lobes is rare and termed multilobate. However, more frequently, one or more small accessory lobes – succenturiate lobes – may develop in the membranes at a distance from the main placenta. These lobes have vessels that course through the membranes. If these vessels overlie the cervix to create a vasa previa, they can cause dangerous fetal hemorrhage if torn. An accessory lobe may also be retained in the uterus after delivery and cause postpartum uterine atony and hemorrhage.

  1. Circular fold of amniotic membrane over the fetal side is circumvallate placenta
  2. Marginal insertion of cord is battledore placenta
  3. In furcate placenta the three vessels of the cord divide before getting inserted into the placenta
  4. Placenta spuria is a type of placenta with accessory lobe and a communicating vessel in between

questions.text: A mother brings her 19 year old daughter to OPD with complaints of menarche not attained. On examination breast and pubic hair development is normal but with a blind vagina and uterus not felt. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Causes of primary amenorhea

  1. Anatomic abnormalities of the genital outflow tract
    1. MRKH
    2. Imperforate hymen
    3. Transverse vaginal septum
  2. Hypergonadotrophic hypogonadism
    1. Turner syndrome
    2. 46XX/XY pure gonadal dysgenesis
  3. Hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism
    1. Constitutional delay
    2. Isolated gonadotrophin deficiency
      1. Prader willi syndrome
      2. Kallman syndrome
      3. Laurence moon- biedl syndrome
      4. Neoplasm
    3. Craniopharyngioma
    4. Pituitary adenoma
  4. Langhans cell histiocytosis
  5. Irradiation
  6. Chronic malnutrition
  7. Anorexia nervosa
  8. Antidopaminergic drugs and opiates
  9. Primary hypothyroidism
  10. Cushings syndrome
  11. Cytotoxic drugs

MRKH is characterized by normal height, functioning ovaries, 46XX, normal secondary sexual characters and absent mullerian structures like fallopian tube, uterus, cervix, upper two thirds of vagina. Lower vagina is present like a dimple. Vaginoplasty is indicated before marriage for sexual function.

choices.text: Keep the IUCD in place and continue prophylactic antibiotics in place
Keep the IUCD in place without any treatment
Terminate the pregnancy because of high risk of infection
Remove the IUCD immediately and continue pregnancy

questions.text: A 30 year old lady, G3P2 with 10 weeks intrauterine gestation comes to OPD with an IUCD and the tail of the IUCD is noted to be protruding from the cervical os. The most appropriate course of action is
questions.solution:
Thread visible - Remove the device after explaining the risk of abortion Continuing or terminating the pregnancy is according to patient’s will Thread not visible - Do USG to locate the device

If the thread of the IUCD is not seen, termination of pregnancy is offered not because IUCD is teratogenic but because the risk of uterine infection is considerable.

questions.text: A primigravida with 40+5 weeks was admitted in the labour room for induction. On per vaginal examination it was found cervix with 1cm dilatation/30% effaced/Vx -1, cervix is soft posterior. Bishop score is
questions.solution:
Bishop scoring system used for Assessment of inducibility:



  • Induction of labour is successful with a score of 9 or more and less successful with lower scores.
  • A score < 4 means ripening of cervix is indicated before inducing labour.

A 30 year old primigravida came to OPD with complaints of bleeding per vaginum associated with pain. On examination abdomen is soft and non-tender. Palpation -uterus is enlarged 12 week size, soft non-tender and no cervical excitation. The USG is as shown below. The most probable diagnosis is
questions.solution: The given picture shows complete hydatidiform mole. The characteristic snow storm appearance is due to an echogenic uterine mass that has numerous anechoic cystic spaces with absent fetus and amniotic sac.

questions.text: Most common karyotype associated with complete mole is
Best investigation to diagnose uterine synechea is
questions.solution: Hysteroscopy is both diagnostic and therapeutic and is the best for uterine synechea

questions.text: Hormone not involved in sheehans syndrome is
questions.solution:
Insulin is not secreted by the pituitary and is not involved in sheehans syndrome

Sheehan’s syndrome

Syndrome which results from ischemic necrosis of most of the ant pituitary d/t spasm in the arterioles occuring at the time of severe hemorrhage or shock complicating childbirth

Symptoms

  • Failure of lactation
  • Secondary amenorrhea
  • Loss of libido
  • Increased sensitivity to cold

Lab- decrease levels of Prl, TSH, FSH, LH, ACTH, estrogen & urinary 17- ketosteroids

Treatment life long supplementation of estrogen, progesterone, thyroid & adrenal hormone

questions.text: A 35 yr old lady is not having her menses for last 4 months. She has high serum FSH and LH level with low estradiol. The likely cause is
In a case of secondary amenorrhea who falls to get withdrawal bleeding after taking E and P, the fault lies at the level of
Withdrawal bleeding following adminstration of progesterone in a case of secondary amenorrhea indicates all except
questions.solution: Defect at the level of pituitary or gonad results in total amenorrhea even with progesterone withdrawal

questions.text: 21 year old mrs x with regular and painful cycles has come with history of recurrent first trimester miscarriages with acne and hirsuitism. Ultrasound of the pelvis revealed 14 follicles of each measuring 3 to 6 mm however her cycles were regular. All of the following can be a part of the management except
Most common cause of female infertility is
questions.solution:
Causes of female infertility

Ovarian - 30-40%

Tubal - 25-30%

Uterine - 10%

Cervical - 5%

Peritoneal - 5%

Vaginal

Unexplained - 15% (Includes Other Endocrine Factor)

questions.text: HSG picture of a 28 year old woman with primary infertility revealed the following findings. The ideal next step is
questions.solution: HSG picture showing B/L tubal block could be due to cornual spasm which needs laparoscopy for confirmation

questions.text: All of the following are tests for ovarian reserve except
questions.solution:
Ovarian reserve tests

  • To assess the quantity & quality of primordial follicles present in the women’s ovary
  • Tests are
    • D2 FSH
    • D2 Estradiol
    • D5 serum Inhibin B
    • Serum Antimullerian Hormone (AMH) 5. Antral follicle count
  • Serum FSH- on D2/D3= high= poor ovarian reserve on D10 after CCCT, CC100 mg is given from D5-D9 & on D10 value >10IU/l indicate poor ovarian reserve
  • D2/D3 Serum Estradiol >70-80pg/ml, poor ovarian reserve
  • Inhibin B levels- reduced in advanced age (<40pg/ml)
  • Serum AMH-
    • AMH is produced by the granulosa cells of the preantral follicles
    • AMH levels are not dependent on feedback mechanisms can be measured anytime of the cycle Qualitative marker
  • Antral follicle count-
    • No. of follicle counted in both ovaries by TVS in early follicular phase AFC>6 indicates good ovarian reserve Quantitative marker

questions.text: Risk factors for OHSS are all except
questions.solution:
OHSS - Risk factors

  • Young age of the woman
  • PCOD
  • Increased oestradiol level > 3000 pg/ml
  • 20 or more small follicles
  • Incresed blood flow in doppler
  • Increased rennin and angiotensin factors
  • Vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF).

questions.solution:

  • One sperm is enough to do an icsi
  • Sperms can be obtained by tese/testicular biopsy

advantage

  • Pregnancy rates are high (30 – 60%)

disadvantage

questions.text: Fern Test Is Due To
questions.solution: Under the influence of estrogen cervical mucus becomes thin and watery and becomes profuse in the pre-ovulatory phase

questions.text: Fetal fibronectin is a predictor of
questions.solution: Fetal fibronectin is a predictor of Preterm labour and preeclampsia Cut off for predicting preterm labour is 50ng/ml

questions.text: Resting pulse rate during pregnancy
questions.solution:
• Heart rate increases by 10 beats/min.
  • Pulse rate increases by 10 beats/min.
  • Progesterone is a smooth muscle relaxant. So, as progesterone increases during pregnancy peripheral resistance decreases and peripheral vascular resistance decreases

Cardiac Output (CO)

  • Begins to increase by 5 weeks
  • Maximum during pregnancy at 3 weeks.
  • CO increases by 40% during pregnancy
  • CO increases by 50% during labour.
  • CO increase by 70% in the immediate post-partum period because blood from placenta returns to maternal circulation.
  • CO goes back to pre-pregnant values in about 1 week after delivery.

questions.text: Hormone secreted by both syncitiotrophoblast and cytotrophoblast is

Identify the associated condition
questions.solution: The given picture shows sinusoidal pattern which is seen in fetal anemia as in hydrops fetalis

questions.text: Most severe non D Rhesus alloimmunisation is
questions.solution:
Blood group antigens are ABO antigens, Rhesus antigens and minor antigens

Rhesus antigens are C,c,D,E,e. There is no ‘d’ antigen

Incidence of Rh-ve blood group - 5-10%

All Rhesus antigens are located on short arm of chr.1

Incidence of Rh D alloimmunisation with out ABO incompatibility is 16%

Incidence of Rh D alloimmunisation with ABO incompatibility is 2%

Most common non D Rhesus alloimmunisation is anti E

Most severe non D Rhesus alloimmunisation is anti-c

Minor antigens

  • Kell
  • Duffy group A (anti Fya)
  • anti MNS
  • anti JK Kidd

Fetal hemolysis are not caused by

lewis antibodies Lea, Leb

I antibodies

Duffy group B anti Fyb

Cause of Rh alloimmunisation - pregnancy > blood transfusion

Cause of minor antigen alloimmunisation - blood transfusion > Pregnancy

Kell sensitization due to pregnancy is more severe than Rh-D sensitsation

Features of Kell sensitization due to pregnancy

  • Affects bone narrow erythrocyte precursors
  • Less hematopoesis
  • Less hemolysis and less Jaundice
  • Less antibody titre
  • Ideal investigation is MCA Doppler
